fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A category \mathcal { C } is said to be regular if it is cartesian, has images, and covers are stable under pullback. A functor F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } between regular categories is said to be regular if it is cartesian and preserves covers. Note that since cartesian functors preserve monomorphisms, every regular functor automatically preserves images.

Let F \colon \mathcal { C } \to \mathcal { D } be a regular functor and f \colon A \to B be a morphism in \mathcal { C }. By , f admits a cover-mono factorization f = \mathsf { Img } (f) \vartheta _{f}. Then since F preserves monomorphisms and covers, F( \mathsf { Img } (f))F( \vartheta _{f}) forms a cover-mono factorization of F(f). Then by uniqueness, \mathsf { Img } (Ff) \cong F( \mathsf { Img } (f)).

Let \mathcal { C } be a category with images and equalizers. Then every morphism of \mathcal { C } can be factored as a cover followed by a monomorphism. Moreover, this factorization is unique up to isomorphism in the sense that if A \twoheadrightarrow C \rightarrowtail B and A \twoheadrightarrow C' \rightarrowtail B are both cover-mono factorizations of the same morphism, then C \cong C'.

By the construction of images, every morphism f \colon A \to B can be factored as \mathsf { Img } (f) \vartheta _{f}, where \vartheta is the unit of the image adjunction. \mathsf { Img } (f) is monic by construction and \vartheta _{f} is a cover by .

To show the second half of the lemma, it suffices to show that every cover-mono factorization of a morphism f is isomorphic to \mathsf { Img } (f) \vartheta _{f}. Let hg be a cover-mono factorization of f. Then by the universal property of adjunction, there is a morphism s in \mathsf { Sub } (B) such that s \vartheta _{f} = g. By the definition of \mathsf { Sub } (B), we also have hs = \mathsf { Img } (f). Then, it follows that s is monic.
Since g is extremal, s must be an isomorphism.

An epimorphism f \colon A \twoheadrightarrow B is said to be extremal (also called a cover) if for any monomorphism m \colon C \rightarrowtail B and any morphism g \colon A \to C such that f = mg, then m is an isomorphism.

A category \mathcal { C } is said to have images if the inclusion functor \mathsf { Sub } (A) \hookrightarrow { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} admits a left adjoint \mathsf { Img } \colon { \mathcal { C } _{/{ A }}} \to \mathsf { Sub } (A) for all objects A \in \mathcal { C }.
